{{Multiple issues| {{COI|date=August 2017}} {{update|date=June 2017}} }} {{Infobox non-profit | name = Ushahidi, Inc. | image = | type = [[501(c)(3)]] | tax_id = 2652079 | founded_date = 2008 | founder = [[Erik Hersman]], [[Ory Okolloh]], [[Juliana Rotich]], [[David Kobia]] | location = [[Nairobi]], Kenya | coordinates = | origins = [[Crowdsourcing]] | key_people = [[Erik Hersman]], Juliana Rotich, David Kobia, | area_served = World | focus = activism, [[Cartography|mapping]] | method = [[Cartography|mapping]] and [[geospatial]] | revenue = US$2,500,000–$4,000,000 | endowment = US$1,800,000<ref name="tr50">{{cite web |url= http://www.technologyreview.com/companywatch/company/ushahidi/ |title= Top50 Private Web Companies}}</ref> | num_volunteers = 50 | num_employees = 31 | owner = Ushahidi, Inc. | motto = Raise Your Voice | former name = | homepage = {{URL|ushahidi.com}} | dissolved = | footnotes = }}{{Use British English|date=May 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2014}}
'''Ushahidi, Inc.''' is a non-profit technology company with staff in nine countries whose mission is to help marginalized people raise their voice and those who serve them to listen and respond better.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ushahidi.com/about|title=About Ushahidi|website=Ushahidi|language=en-US|access-date=2017-08-14}}</ref> It has been instrumental in creating the Kenyan tech ecosystem, known as the Silicon Savannah, and its employees have gone on to found iHub, Akirachix, and BRCK.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2016/11/02/kenyan-startup-ushahidi-launches-a-crowdsourced-campaign-to-monitor-the-u-s-election/|title=Kenyan startup Ushahidi launches a crowdsourced campaign to monitor the U.S. election {{!}} TechCrunch|last=Bright|first=Jake|access-date=2017-08-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/tobyshapshak/2015/07/29/why-kenyan-tech-entrepreneurs-deserve-all-obamas-praise/#12ebd7857068|title=Why Kenyan Tech Entrepreneurs Deserve All Obama's Praise|last=Shapshak|first=Toby|work=Forbes|access-date=2017-08-14|language=en}}</ref>
The organisation uses the concept of [[crowdsourcing]] for social activism and public accountability, serving as an initial model for what has been coined as "activist mapping"—the combination of social activism, [[citizen journalism]] and [[geospatial]] information. Ushahidi offers products that enable local observers to submit reports using their mobile phones or the internet, while simultaneously creating a temporal and geospatial archive of events.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.pcmag.com/feature/288952/the-tech-tools-of-political-revolution/8#fbid=Q78O4eF6bPV|title=The Tech Tools of Political Revolution|work=PCMAG|access-date=2017-08-14|language=en}}</ref> The Ushahidi platform is often used for crisis response, human rights reporting, and election monitoring.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ushahidi.com|title=Ushahidi|website=Ushahidi|language=en-US|access-date=2017-08-14}}</ref> Ushahidi offers products that enable local observers to submit reports using their mobile phones or the internet, while simultaneously creating a temporal and geospatial archive of events. Ushahidi ([[Swahili language|Swahili]] for "testimony", closely related to shahidi which means "witness") created a website in the aftermath of [[2007–08 Kenyan crisis|Kenya's disputed 2007 presidential election]] that collected eyewitness reports of violence reported by email and text message and placed them on a [[Google Maps]] map.<ref name="CNET">{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnet.com/news/facebook-messenger-bots-help-monitor-kenya-election-violence/|title=Facebook Messenger bots help monitor Kenya election violence|work=CNET|access-date=2017-08-14|language=en}}</ref>
The Ushahidi platform has been deployed over 125,000 times in over 160 countries,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nation.co.ke/lifestyle/DN2/How-many-Ushahidi-like-cases-are-there-that-remain-hidden/957860-4031728-4c0nid/index.html|title=#FRONTROW: How many Ushahidi-like cases remain hidden?|work=Daily Nation|access-date=2017-08-14|language=en-UK}}</ref><ref name="CNET"/> used by The Obama Campaign for America 2012,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ushahidi.com/blog/2016/05/06/how-ushahidi-helped-thousands-of-peoples-votes-count-in-the-2012-usa-election|title=How Ushahidi Helped Thousands of Peoples' Votes Count in the 2012 USA Election|website=Ushahidi|language=en-US|access-date=2017-08-14}}</ref> The United Nations Department of Field Services and Peacekeeping,<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=g3oqDwAAQBAJ&pg=PA211&lpg=PA211&dq=un+sage+ushahidi&source=bl&ots=xu1JpioW5y&sig=HN77cpkkLTqUzHjPosxARgWClOE&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj70NHRu9fVAhXLw1QKHZKnB_kQ6AEIMjAC#v=onepage&q=un%20sage%20ushahidi&f=false|title=Perspectives on Military Intelligence from the First World War to Mali: Between Learning and Law|last=Baudet|first=Floribert|last2=Braat|first2=Eleni|last3=Woensel|first3=Jeoffrey van|last4=Wever|first4=Aad|date=2017-07-30|publisher=Springer|isbn=9789462651838|language=en}}</ref> in response to the Haiti Earthquake in 2010,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://sites.google.com/site/haitiushahidieval/news/finalreportindependentevaluationoftheushahidihaitiproject|title=Final Report: Independent Evaluation of the Ushahidi Haiti Project - Ushahidi Haiti Independent Evaluation|website=sites.google.com|access-date=2017-08-14}}</ref> to monitor the Nigerian elections in 2011,<ref name="Bailard 349–367">{{Cite journal|last=Bailard|first=Catie Snow|last2=Livingston|first2=Steven|date=2014-10-02|title=Crowdsourcing Accountability in a Nigerian Election|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/19331681.2014.947056|journal=Journal of Information Technology & Politics|volume=11|issue=4|pages=349–367|doi=10.1080/19331681.2014.947056|issn=1933-1681}}</ref> by the Nepalese army to respond to the earthquake of 2015,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nepalarmy.mil.np/opssankatmochan/english_part1.pdf|title=Nepal Army and Disaster Management Report|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170724171126/http://www.nepalarmy.mil.np/opssankatmochan/english_part1.pdf|archive-date=2017-07-24|dead-url=yes|access-date=}}</ref> in and by local activists groups such as Humanitarian Tracker to monitor violence in the Syrian civil war<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.humanitariantracker.org/syria-tracker|title=Humanitarian Tracker|website=Humanitarian Tracker|access-date=2017-08-14}}</ref> and [[HARASSmap|HarassMap]] to help women report on sexual harassment.<ref>{{Cite news|author=Chelsea Young|url=https://timreview.ca/article/770|title=HarassMap: Using Crowdsourced Data to Map Sexual Harassment in Egypt|publisher=Technology Innovation Management Review|date=March 2014|access-date=2018-07-21|}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://harassmap.org/ar/|title=خريطة التحرش {{!}} معأ لخلق بيئة رافضة للتحرش الجنسي في مصر|website=harassmap.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-08-14}}</ref>
== Products == === Ushahidi v3 === Ushahidi v3 was released in September 2015. As an improvement to the v2 platform it is built as an API with a web client. It allows for custom survey creation, and the running of multiple surveys on a single deployment, amongst other feature improvements from v2 such as embeddable maps and surveys, analytics, private deployments, and management of roles and permissions.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ushahidi.com/plans-detail|title=Plans|website=Ushahidi|language=en-US|access-date=2017-08-10}}</ref> It is built on the Laravel PHP web framework. It is open source under the AGPL license.<ref>{{Citation|title=platform: Ushahidi Platform v3 API|date=2017-07-21|url=https://github.com/ushahidi/platform|publisher=Ushahidi|accessdate=2017-08-10}}</ref>
=== Ushahidi v2 === Ushahidi v2 is built on the [[Kohana (web framework)|Kohana]] web framework, a fork of the [[CodeIgniter#CodeIgniter|CodeIgniter]] framework. It includes support for Nexmo wholesale SMS API and Clickatell SMS Gateway. Furthermore, the official Ushahidi-hosted websites use the commercial service.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.clickatell.com/press/press_article.php/154|title=SMS Helps Provide Instant SOS During Times of Crisis – Clickatell and Ushahidi Urge Support to Haiti}}</ref> Ushahidi provides the option of using [[OpenStreetMap]] maps in its user interface, but requires the [[Google Maps]] API for [[geocoding]]. Ushahidi is often set up using a local SMS gateway created by a local [[FrontlineSMS]] set-up.
====Releases and codenames==== * '''1.0 Mogadishu''' – 10 December 2009 * '''1.2 Haiti''' – ~22 January 2010 * '''2.0 Luanda''' – 22 November 2010 * '''2.1 Tunis''' – 9 August 2011 * '''2.2 Juba''' – 13 March 2012 * '''2.3 Juba''' – 24 April 2012
===Crowdmap=== {{See also|Crowdmapping}} Crowdmap is designed and built by the team behind Ushahidi, a platform that was originally built to crowdsource crisis information. As the platform evolved, so did its users.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://lifehacker.com/5612368/crowdmap-puts-any-data-on-an-interactive-map|title=Crowdmap Puts Any Data on an Interactive Map|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|accessdate=}}</ref> Crowdmap now allows users to set up their own deployments of Ushahidi without having to install it on a web server. Since its release in 2010, prominent deployments of Crowdmap have documented the global [[Occupy movement]] and the [[2011 London anti-cuts protest]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pcmag.com/slideshow/story/288952/the-tech-tools-of-political-revolution/8#fbid=Q78O4eF6bPV|title=The Tech Tools of Political Revolution}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://map.15october.net/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110930132624/http://map.15october.net/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2011-09-30|title=15 October 2011}}</ref> The original Crowdmap was a hosted version of the Ushahidi v2 open source software platform.
On 31 December 2010, the Ushahidi team announced a new version of Crowdmap, that differed from the Ushahidi v2 codebase: Checkins, a geosocial add-on to Crowdmap that allows users to create a [[White-label product|white-label]] alternative to sites like [[Foursquare]] and [[Gowalla]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.ushahidi.com/index.php/2010/12/31/announcing-checkins-for-ushahidi-and-crowdmap/|title=Announcing Checkins for Ushahidi and Crowdmap}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://readwrite.com/2011/01/03/check-ins_with_a_purpose_with_crisis-mapping_ushah#awesm=~okeEErmHcnhLYe|title=Checkins with a Purpose|publisher=ReadWrite}}</ref> Rather than filling out submission forms online, checkins allow Crowdmap users to expedite data entry to their deployment, focussing first on location and adding more detailed information later.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.geospatialworld.net/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=21289%3Aushahidi-launches-crowdmap-checkins&catid=42%3Aproduct-gis&Itemid=1|title=Ushahidid launches Crowdmap Checkins}}</ref> Ushahidi describes the effort as "checkins with a purpose".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.cnn.com/2011-03-29/tech/ushahidi.checkin.map_1_check-ins-gowalla-map?_s=PM:TECH|title=Ushahidid tests 'checkin' Funciton|date=23 August 2010|work=CNN|access-date=25 October 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110827011736/http://articles.cnn.com/2011-03-29/tech/ushahidi.checkin.map_1_check-ins-gowalla-map?_s=PM:TECH|archive-date=27 August 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
=== SwiftRiver (discontinued) === SwiftRiver was designed as a suite of intelligence and real-time data gathering products that complement Ushahidi's mapping and visualization products. Often referred to as ''the SwiftRiver Initiative'' the goal of the project was "to democratize access to the tools for making sense of information". The project attracted a lot of interest from newsrooms.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.wired.co.uk/magazine/archive/2010/10/start/tagging-a-crisis|title=SwiftRiver: Tagging a Crisis|last=Kirwan|first=Peter|newspaper=Wired.co.uk|accessdate=15 October 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131015111740/http://www.wired.co.uk/magazine/archive/2010/10/start/tagging-a-crisis|archive-date=15 October 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In December 2014, Ushahidi announced that it would stop development and support and reallocate the resources.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ushahidi.com/2014/12/08/bittersweet-farewell-swiftriver/|title=Bittersweet Farewell to SwiftRiver|website=Ushahidi|accessdate=2015-05-28}}</ref>
SwiftRiver was a free and [[Open-source platform]] that helped people make sense of a lot of information in a short amount of time. It was born out of the need to understand and act upon a wave of massive amounts of crisis data that tends to overwhelm in the first 24 hours of a disaster. There had been a great deal of interest in Swift for other industries such as newsrooms, political analysts and marketers as an open-source alternative to more expensive, proprietary intelligence software platforms. The SwiftRiver platform offered applications which combine natural language/artificial intelligence process, [[Data mining|data-mining]] for SMS and Twitter, and verification algorithms for different sources of information.{{Citation needed|date=June 2017}}
=== Rollcall === Ushahidi built [https://www.rollcall.io/ RollCall] after a team member was involved in the terrorist attack at Westgate Malle in Nairobi in 2013. Rollcall is a quick way to check in with the people someone is responsible for during critical situations. Rollcall sends a one-click message with a binary question such as "Are you okay?" to a pre-prepared contact list, such as list of colleagues, parents at a school, or an embassy's list of citizens in a country at that time, via text, email, mobile app, and Slack. The recipients respond with a "yes" or "no" allowing the organization responsible for them to quickly triage who is in danger.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.rollcall.io/|title=RollCall|website=www.rollcall.io|access-date=2017-08-10}}</ref>
==History== [[File:Juliana Rotich.jpg|thumb|Juliana Rotich]] ===Beginnings in Kenya=== Ushahidi ([[Swahili language|Swahili]] for "testimony" or "witness") is a website created in the aftermath of Kenya's disputed 2007 presidential election (see [[2007–2008 Kenyan crisis]]) that collected eyewitness reports of violence sent in by email and text-message and placed them on a [[Google map]].<ref name="forbes">{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/global/2008/1208/114.html|title=Citizen Voices|author=Megha Baree|date=20 November 2008|work=Forbes Magazine|accessdate=15 January 2010}}</ref> It is also the name of the [[Open-source software|open source]] software developed for that site, which has since been improved, released freely, and used for a number of similar projects around the globe.
The Kenyan site was developed and run by several bloggers and software developers, all current or former residents of Kenya. They include [[Erik Hersman]], [[Juliana Rotich]], [[Ory Okolloh]], and [[David Kobia]].<ref name="venture">{{cite web |url= https://venturebeat.com/2008/01/15/kenyan-tech-bloggers-launch-crisis-report-site/|title= Kenyan tech bloggers launch crisis-report site |author= David Adewumi |date= 15 January 2008 |work= VentureBeat |accessdate=16 January 2010}}</ref> The site was initially proposed by Okolloh, developed cheaply, and put online within a few days.<ref name="venture" /><ref>{{cite web |url= http://static.rnw.nl/migratie/www.radionetherlands.nl/thestatewerein/otherstates/twsi-081206-Kenya-violence-redirected |archive-url= https://archive.is/20120714063214/http://static.rnw.nl/migratie/www.radionetherlands.nl/thestatewerein/otherstates/twsi-081206-Kenya-violence-redirected |dead-url= yes |archive-date= 14 July 2012 |title= Mapping violence in Kenya |author= Chris Chambers |date= 12 May 2008 |work= Radio Netherlands Worldwide |accessdate= 16 January 2010 }}</ref> International media, government sources, NGOs, and Kenyan journalists and bloggers were used to verify eyewitness testimony.<ref name="venture" /><ref name="csm">{{cite web |url= http://www.csmonitor.com/World/terrorism-security/2008/0131/p99s01-duts.html?s=rel |title= Cellphone and Internet access helps – and hinders – accurate reporting in Kenya |author= Peter Smith |date= 31 January 2008 |work= Christian Science Monitor |accessdate=16 January 2010}}</ref><ref name="mshale">{{cite web |url= http://mshale.com/article.cfm?articleID=18192 |title= Kenyan Techie Honored for Role in Tracking Post-election Violence |author= Dorcas Komo |date= 3 July 2008 |work= Mshale |accessdate=16 January 2010}}</ref> The site was later also used to facilitate donations from abroad.<ref name="mshale" />
An analysis by [[Harvard University|Harvard's]] [[Kennedy School of Government]] found that Ushahidi was better overall at reporting acts of violence as they began. The data collected by Ushahidi was superior to that reported by the mainstream media in [[Kenya]] at the time. The service was also better at reporting non-fatal violence as well as information coming in from rural areas.<ref>[[Clay Shirky|Shirky, Clay]]. 2010. ''[[Cognitive Surplus: Creativity and Generosity in a Connected Age]]''. New York: Penguin Press. 16.</ref>
On 23 December 2010, Ushahidi Co-founder and Executive Director [[Ory Okolloh]] announced that she was stepping down from her role to become Manager of Policy for Africa at [[Google]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/technology/2010/12/google-hires-kenyan-activist-ory-okolloh-as-policy-manager-for-africa.html|title=Google hires Kenyan activist Ory Okolloh as policy manager for Africa | work=Los Angeles Times}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kenyanpundit.com/2010/12/23/stepping-down-as-ushahidi-executive-director/|title=Stepping Down as Ushahidi Executive Director}}</ref>
===Post-Kenya crisis uses=== Soon after its initial use in Kenya, the Ushahidi software was used to create a similar site to track [[Xenophobia in South Africa#May 2008 riots|anti-immigrant violence in South Africa]], in May 2008.<ref name="mshale" /><ref name="NYTimes">{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/05/23/world/africa/23iht-23saf.13165981.html | work=The New York Times | title=Anti-immigrant violence spreads in South Africa, with attacks reported in Cape Town | date=23 May 2008}}</ref> The software has since been used to map violence in eastern Congo, beginning in November 2008.<ref name="forbes" /><ref>{{cite news |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/technology/7773648.stm |title= Web tool maps Congo conflict |author= Alka Marwaha |date= 10 December 2008 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=16 January 2010}}</ref> Ushahidi is used in Kenya, Malawi, Uganda, and Zambia in June 2009 to track pharmacy [[stockout]]s in several Southeast African countries.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.pcworld.com/article/169416/mobiles_help_put_a_stop_to_drug_stockouts.html%3C |title= Mobiles Help Put a Stop to Drug Stock-outs |author= Ken Banks |date= 31 July 2009 |work= Pc World |accessdate=16 January 2010}}</ref> Finally, it was used to monitor elections in Mexico and India, among other projects.<ref name="infoworld">{{cite web |url= http://www.infoworld.com/d/cloud-computing/technology-elevates-africas-global-status-494 |title= Technology elevates Africa's global status |author= Rebecca Wanjiku |date= 12 August 2009 |work= Computerworld |publisher= Infoworld |accessdate= 16 January 2010 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20110608082752/http://www.infoworld.com/d/cloud-computing/technology-elevates-africas-global-status-494 |archive-date= 8 June 2011 |dead-url= yes |df= dmy-all }}</ref> It was also used by [[Al Jazeera]] to collect eyewitness reports during the 2008–09 [[Gaza War (2008–09)|Gaza War]].<ref name="infoworld" /><ref>{{cite web |url=http://labs.aljazeera.net/warongaza |title=War on Gaza – Experimental Beta |publisher=Labs.aljazeera.net |accessdate=1 May 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110228053334/http://labs.aljazeera.net/warongaza/ |archive-date=28 February 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Ekine|first=Sokari|title=Ushahidi Platform Used to Document Congo, Gaza Crises|url=https://www.pbs.org/mediashift/2009/01/ushahidi-platform-used-to-document-congo-gaza-crises009.html|work=MediaShift|publisher=Public Broadcasting Service|accessdate=19 March 2011|date=9 January 2009}}</ref>
The post election violence in Kenya was the subject of a Harvard Humanitarian Institute study and mentioned in a Berkman Center report.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://irevolution.wordpress.com/2008/10/23/mapping-kenyas-election-violence/|title=Crisis Mapping Kenya's Election Violence}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://cyber.law.harvard.edu/publications/2008/Digitally_Networked_Technology_Kenyas_Post-Election_Crisis|title=Digitally Networked Technology in Kenya's 2007–2008 Post-Election Crisis}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://browse.oecdbookshop.org/oecd/pdfs/browseit/4309141E.PDF |title=Conflict and Fragility : Preventing Violence, War and State Collapse |format=PDF |accessdate=1 May 2010}}</ref>
===2010===
====Haiti==== In 2010, due to the [[2010 Haiti earthquake|earthquake in Haiti]], Patrick Meier launched a joint effort between Ushahidi, The Fletcher School of Law & Diplomacy at Tufts University, [[Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs|UN OCHA]]/Colombia and the International Network of Crisis Mappers (CM*Net) to start the Haiti implementation. A few hours later many humanitarian/tech workers joined this initiative.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/01/12/gleaning-information-from-haiti-online/ |title=Tuesday and Wednesday's Updates on Haiti's Earthquake |first1=Robert |last1=Mackey |first2=Nick |last2=Corasaniti |date=12 January 2010 |work=New York Times |accessdate=16 January 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/01/15/AR2010011502650.html |title= Crisis mapping brings online tool to Haitian disaster relief effort |author= Monica Hesse |date= 16 January 2010 |work= Washington Post|accessdate=16 January 2010}}</ref> Nearly 40,000 independent reports were sent to the Ushahidi Haiti Project of which nearly 4,000 distinct events were plotted.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.alnap.org/pool/files/uhp-eval-executive-summary-prelim-findings-1-12-11-draftb[2].pdf|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20111108092116/http://www.alnap.org/pool/files/uhp-eval-executive-summary-prelim-findings-1-12-11-draftb%5B2%5D.pdf|dead-url= yes|archive-date= 2011-11-08|title= Independent Evaluation of the Ushahidi Haiti Project}}</ref>
====Chile==== Only a month after the Haiti earthquake, the [[2010 Chile earthquake|2010 earthquake]] in Chile prompted Patrick Meier to launch Ushahidi-Chile within hours of the initial quake.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/technology/8543671.stm ''Net puts Kenya at centre of Chile rescue efforts''], Jonathan Fildes, [[BBC News]], 1 March 2010</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://chile.ushahidi.com/ |title=Ushahidi Chile |publisher=Chile.ushahidi.com |accessdate=1 May 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100523232735/http://chile.ushahidi.com/ |archive-date=23 May 2010 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The Chile site is co-managed with the [[School of International and Public Affairs, Columbia University]] in the United States, supported by [[Chilean American]]s.
====Louisiana, U.S.==== On 20 April 2010 BP’s offshore [[Deepwater Horizon|Deepwater Horizon oil rig]] exploded killing eleven workers and precipitating the [[Deepwater Horizon oil spill|largest accidental offshore oil spill]] in the history of the petroleum industry.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/news/nation/2010-05-27-oil-spill-news_N.htm|title=Gulf oil spill now largest offshore spill in history as BP continues plug effort|publisher=USA Today|date=27 May 2010|last=Staff and wire}}</ref> On 3 May the [[Louisiana Bucket Brigade]] (LABB) publicly released the Oil Spill Crisis Map, the first application of the Ushahidi platform in a humanitarian response in the United States.{{citation needed|date=June 2017}}
In the years since the BP oil spill, LABB continues to use the map (now the iWitness Pollution Map) as a repository of eyewitness reports and photos documenting the impacts of petrochemical pollution on human health and the environment. Reports to the map come from cities all over Louisiana, including Baton Rouge, St. Rose, and Chalmette. Since 2010 LABB has collected over 14,000<ref>{{cite web|url=http://iwitnesspollution.org|title=iWitness Pollution Map|publisher=Louisiana Bucket Brigade|accessdate=4 December 2014}}</ref> reports, making it the largest and longest-running deployment of an Ushahidi instance.{{citation needed|date=June 2017}}
====Washington, D.C.==== In the wake of [[February 5–6, 2010 North American blizzard|winter storms]], the ''[[Washington Post]]'' and the web development company PICnet used the software to create a site mapping blocked roads and other information.<ref name="Giridharadas">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/03/14/weekinreview/14giridharadas.html?scp=1&sq=ushahidi&st=cse|title=Africa's Gift to Silicon Valley: How to Track a Crisis|last=Giridharadas|first=Anand|date=12 March 2010|work=New York Times|accessdate=16 March 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://snowmageddoncleanup.com/page/index/2|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100214223123/http://www.snowmageddoncleanup.com/page/index/2|dead-url=yes|archive-date=14 February 2010|title=Who's Behind This?|work=Snowmageddon: The Clean Up|accessdate=16 March 2010}}</ref>
====Italy==== Elena Rapisardi, together with Giovanni Lotto, launched the first Italian crowdmap Open Foreste Italiane in order to list and map information to prevent and manage forest fires; the meaning of this project has been reported on the Ushahidi blog.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.ushahidi.com/2010/05/05/ushahidi-used-in-italy-to-prevent-forest-fires |title= Ushahidi Used in Italy to Prevent Forest Fires |author= Monica Palmeri |date= 5 May 2010 |work= Ushahidi Blog}}</ref>
Though OpenForeste did not completely achieve his goals, it showed importance for two reasons: (1) unlike previous instances, the platform was utilized in absence of an acting crisis or emergency to collect, map, share and spread information in order to manage future and potential emergencies, thus joining the awareness of the possibilities of [[Web 2.0]] and a different approach to natural risk prevention;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.web2expo.com/webexny2009/public/schedule/speaker/61873 |title=See speech at Web 2.0 Expo on 2009 |publisher=Web2expo.com |date= |accessdate=10 August 2014}}</ref> (2) it brought to Italy the knowledge and potential of Ushahidi, [[crowdmapping]] and social use of [[crowdsourcing]], which was then used in following years in several instances, both private and public, especially from local Civil Protection structures and based on the new approach to the Ushahidi platform (see here a non-complete crowdmap of Italian Crowdsourcing Projects).
====Russia==== Ushahidi was used in Russia to set up a "map of help" for voluntary workers needed after the [[2010 Russian wildfires]].{{citation needed|date=June 2017}}
===2011=== ;Christchurch Using Ushahidi, the [[Christchurch Recovery Map]] website was launched less than 24 hours after the February [[2011 Christchurch earthquake]] in Christchurch, New Zealand. The site maps locations of services such as food, water, toilets, fuel, [[Automated teller machine|ATM]]<nowiki/>s, and medical care. Information was gathered via Twitter using the #eqnz hashtag, SMS messages, and email. The site was founded by a group of web professionals, and maintained by volunteers.{{citation needed|date=June 2017}}
;Middle East This software allowed pro-democracy demonstrators across the Middle East to organise and communicate what was happening around them in early 2011.<ref>http://blog.ushahidi.com/?s=egypt&submit_button=Search</ref> On 2 March, the UN [[Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs]] (OCHA) requested that the Standby Volunteer Task Force be activated for Libya.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://blog.standbytaskforce.com/?p=345|title = The Volunteers Behind the Libya Crisis Map: A True Story|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> The Task Force's Tech Team set up a password protected Ushahidi platform almost immediately and several days later launched a public version at OCHA's request. This allowed users to contribute relevant information about ground conditions as they occurred.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://blog.ushahidi.com/2011/03/06/using-new-ushahidi-map-libya/|title = Using the New Ushahidi Platform to Crisis Map Libya|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
;Italy
In July 2011, Giuseppe Calamita<ref>{{cite web|url = http://linkem.crowdmap.com|title = WIMAX LTE Crowdmap Monitoring}}</ref> had created the first crowdmap to monitor a WIMAX/LTE Internet Service Provider to answer the issues not due to the ISP (jammer, etc.){{citation needed|date=June 2017}}
;India India Citizen Reports has been using Ushahidi since 2011 to collect and disseminate reports in various categories like civic problems, crimes and corruption. TelecomMap.com uses Ushahidi to map [[3G]] network quality and Wi-Fi hotspots.{{citation needed|date=June 2017}}
;Australia [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] used Ushahidi to map the [[Queensland]] floods in January.<ref>[http://www.abc.net.au/technology/articles/2011/01/13/3112261.htm ABC's crowdsourced flood-mapping initiative] abc.net</ref>
;United States The MightyMoRiver Project used Ushahidi's hosted service Crowdmap to track the [[2011 Missouri River floods|Missouri River floods of 2011]].{{citation needed|date=June 2017}}
;Macedonia Transparency Watch Project is using the Ushahidi platform to track corruption reported cases in the Republic of Macedonia. PrijaviKorupcija is a joint project by Transparency International and the Center for International Relations allowing citizens to report cases of corruption via [[One (Telekom Slovenija Group)|ONE]] by sending SMS from their mobile phones, sending an email, using the web form, the hashtag #korupcijaMK on Twitter or by reporting via phone call.{{citation needed|date=June 2017}}
'''Nigerian Elections'''
Ushahidi was used to monitor the Nigerian 2011 elections under the project Reclaim Naija. A published article in the Journal of Information Technology & Politics by Catie Snow Bailard & Steven Livingston showed that, "Controlling for a number of factors, we find that the number and nature of crowdmap reports generated by citizens is significantly correlated with increased voter turnout (by 8%) in the 2011 Nigerian presidential election as a result of providing officials with improved information about the functionality of local polling stations."<ref name="Bailard 349–367"/>
===2012=== ;Balkans (Bosnia and Herzegovina, Serbia, Montenegro, Macedonia)
[[Al Jazeera Balkans]] deployed Ushahidi crisis mapping platform on 5 February 2012 to track the snow/cold emergency in the [[Balkans]].<ref>[http://ec2-46-51-135-144.eu-west-1.compute.amazonaws.com/AJB/Feb2012/] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120213110919/http://ec2-46-51-135-144.eu-west-1.compute.amazonaws.com/AJB/Feb2012/ |date=13 February 2012 }} Snjezna oluja nad Balkanom</ref>
===2013=== '''Kenya Elections'''
Ushahidi helped run the Uchaguzi partnership to monitor the 2013 Kenyan elections. The deployment gathered over 8000 reports, a report "Uchaguzi: A Qualitative and Quantitive Analysis of ICTS, Statebuilding, and Peacebuilding in Kenya." showed that 75% of reporters said their report was responded to.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.global.asc.upenn.edu/publications/uchaguzi-a-qualitative-and-quantitative-analysis-of-icts-statebuilding-and-peacebuilding-in-kenya/|title=Uchaguzi: A Qualitative and Quantitative Analysis of ICTS, Statebuilding, and Peacebuilding in Kenya|website=CGCS Media Wire|language=en-US|access-date=2017-08-10}}</ref>
===2014=== '''Kenya'''
Ushahidi announced Ping (now called Rollcall) in response to the attacks on Westgate Mall in Nairobi.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://opensource.com/life/13/9/ushahidi-kenya-mall-siege|title = Software company Ushahidi uses open source skills to help during Kenya mall siege|date = 24 September 2013|accessdate = |website = opensource.com|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> The software was used to map out all the blood drive center locations in Nairobi and let users quickly identify places to donate, see which blood types were in demand, and identify whether equipment or volunteers were needed at any locations. Among the goals of this map was to help ensure that when the Kenyan population came out to donate blood, they would know which donation centers needed their blood type the most.{{citation needed|date=June 2017}}
=== 2015 === Crowd sourced data were extensively used during the relief and rescue operations at Quakemap.org. Kathmandu Living Labs (KLL), a volunteer organization, set up a platform to collect and manage data from crowd using Ushahidi. KLL further managed to conduct first level of verification as well, providing the Nepalese Army with the following details: location, number of affected people, number of death/injured, support requirements, level of urgency, and contact information.
The Nepalese army report said that "Crowd Sourcing is one of the common approaches to collect information from the public. Although it is not new in the context of disaster management, but during April Earthquake in Nepal, this approach was appropriately used in a matured way. The systematic process defined by Kathmandu Living Labs volunteers marked a path in utilization of crowd sourced data by implementing agency like Nepalese Army."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nepalarmy.mil.np/opssankatmochan/english_part1.pdf|title=|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170724171126/http://www.nepalarmy.mil.np/opssankatmochan/english_part1.pdf|archive-date=2017-07-24|dead-url=yes|access-date=}}</ref>
=== 2016 === Ushahidi created USAelectionmonitor.com to monitor the USA 2016 Presidential Election.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/tobyshapshak/2016/11/08/kenyan-real-time-reporting-tool-ushahidi-launches-us-elections-monitoring-service/#4eac10977ca9|title=Kenyan Real-Time Reporting Tool Ushahidi Launches US Elections Monitoring Service|last=Shapshak|first=Toby|work=Forbes|access-date=2017-08-10|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://qz.com/838811/kenyan-crisis-mapping-platform-ushahidi-is-tracking-post-election-violence-in-america/|title=Kenyan crisis-mapping platform Ushahidi is tracking post-election violence in America|last=Kuo|first=Lily|work=Quartz|access-date=2017-08-10|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2016/11/02/kenyan-startup-ushahidi-launches-a-crowdsourced-campaign-to-monitor-the-u-s-election/|title=Kenyan startup Ushahidi launches a crowdsourced campaign to monitor the U.S. election {{!}} TechCrunch|last=Bright|first=Jake|access-date=2017-08-10}}</ref> After the election Ushahidi set up Documenthate.org to monitor the spike in hate crimes against minorities in the USA post election. Ushahidi partnered with journalist and activist [[Shaun King]] and non-profit journalism group Propublica.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://projects.propublica.org/graphics/hatecrimes|title=Documenting Hate - ProPublica|last=ProPublica|work=ProPublica|access-date=2017-08-10|language=en}}</ref> The New Yorker covered the story, saying: "Now Shaun King, a writer for the ''Daily News'', is working with the open-source software company Ushahidi to create a map of post-election intimidation. “Thousands of people have emailed me incident reports over the past seven days,” King wrote me in an e-mail. “The team at Ushahidi is helping me go through them, verify them the best we can, catalogue and then map them, then share them.” The aim is to raise awareness of politically motivated violence and help people stay safe, report it to authorities as needed, and create a database of such incidents."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.newyorker.com/news/news-desk/hate-on-the-rise-after-trumps-election|title=Hate on the Rise After Trump’s Election|website=The New Yorker|access-date=2017-08-10}}</ref>
=== 2017 === Ushahidi ran the Uchaguzi partnership to monitor the 2017 Kenyan elections, the fourth country-wide election monitoring effort for the organization. Ushahidi integrated a Facebook Messenger bot to allow the 7 million Facebook users in Kenya to report via Messenger.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnet.com/au/news/facebook-messenger-bots-help-monitor-kenya-election-violence/|title=Facebook Messenger bots help monitor Kenya election violence|work=CNET|access-date=2017-08-10|language=en}}</ref> The platform received over 7000 reports on election day.
==Awards== Ushahidi has received several awards in recognition to its effectiveness and creativity, latest being The MacArthur Award.<ref>[http://blog.ushahidi.com/category/awards/] Official blog from Ushahidi</ref> The awards received by Ushahidi so far include the following: * The MacArthur Award – 2013<ref>[http://blog.ushahidi.com/2013/02/28/nairobi-announcing-the-macarthur-award-to-ushahidi/] The MacArthur Award</ref> * Global Adaptation Index Prize – 2012<ref>[http://blog.ushahidi.com/2012/05/21/ushahidi-wins-global-adaptation-index-prize/] Global Adaptation Index Prize, May 2012</ref> * Funding of US$1.4 million from the [[Omidyar|Omidyar Network]]<ref>[http://blog.ushahidi.com/2011/12/09/nairobi-announcing-funding-from-omidyar-network/] Funding from [[Omidyar]] 1.4m</ref>
== Criticism ==
=== Sexual harassment allegations === On July 9, 2017, allegations surfaced online of Ushahidi covering up a sexual harassment incident perpetrated by one of the members of their senior leadership.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://techmoran.com/kenyas-ushahidi-reportedly-covering-executives-accused-sexual-harassment/|title=Kenya's Ushahidi reportedly protecting its senior executive accused of sexual harassment - TechMoran|date=2017-07-09|work=TechMoran|access-date=2017-08-16|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://qz.com/1026890/kenyas-ushahidi-is-investigating-sexual-harassment-claims-against-a-senior-employee/|title=Kenya’s vibrant tech sector has been hit with its first sexual harassment scandal|last=Dahir|first=Abdi Latif|work=Quartz|access-date=2017-08-16|language=en-US}}</ref> Ushahidi released a statement the next day confirming they were aware of the allegations which were the subject of an ongoing internal inquiry.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ushahidi.com/blog/2017/07/10/statement-from-ushahidi-board-on-alleged-sexual-harassment-claim|title=Statement from Ushahidi Board on alleged sexual harassment claim|website=Ushahidi|language=en-US|access-date=2017-08-16}}</ref>
Former Ushahidi board member and co-founder Ory Okolloh, strongly condemned the laxity with which the board dealt with the issue on Jul 11 saying:
“More clarity on steps that have been taken so far and the relevant timelines should be shared and those found culpable either by their action or inaction should resign”.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://medium.com/@ookolloh/no-sacred-cows-ea835a78ab37|title=No Sacred Cows|last=Okolloh|first=Ory|date=2017-07-11|website=Ory Okolloh|access-date=2017-08-16}}</ref>
Ushahidi released a second statement on July 17, 2017 detailing the chronology of events showed that the incident occurred on January 19, 2017 and was reported to the board on May 4, 2017, and that on May 5th the accused was placed on temporary leave, given due process, and an investigation was undertaken. After back and forth with both parties' lawyers, the board held an inquiry on July 3 and the accused was alerted of his firing 14 days later on July 17 the date of the statement.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ushahidi.com/blog/2017/07/17/update-from-ushahidi-board-on-inquiry-into-alleged-sexual-harassment-complaint|title=Update from Ushahidi board on inquiry into alleged sexual harassment complaint|website=Ushahidi|language=en-US|access-date=2017-08-16}}</ref>
Angela Kabari came out publicly on July 20 as the victim in a Medium post detailing a 6-month ordeal and called for the resignation of the entire Ushahidi board that consisted of [[David Kobia]], [[Erik Hersman]], [[Juliana Rotich]] and Jenny Stefanotti at the time. She identified Daudi Were, Ushahidi's Executive Director, as the accused. Her statement to the board when she reported the matter included an un-notarized transcript of the recording of the incident and claimed an earlier occurrence the previous year. In her post, she said she encountered 11 other victims some of whom were current employees of the organisation and that the board members were aware of Daudi's misconduct in separate incidents spanning 10 years, however, no others came forward. She castigated the board for lack of support, victim shaming, slander, delays and character attacks. Angela resigned on June 28 citing frustration due to “continual stalling and inaction from the board 55 days after my complaint.”<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://medium.com/@AngieWan/dont-raise-your-voice-here-5910b821a2f0|title=Don’t raise your voice here.|last=Kabari|first=Angela|date=2017-07-20|website=Angela Kabari|access-date=2017-08-16}}</ref>
Daudi Were was alerted of his dismissal on July 17th, formally dismissed on July 22, and Ushahidi released an apology to Angela for the harassment she experienced while working at Ushahidi.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ushahidi.com/blog/2017/07/22/ushahidi-board-dismisses-executive-director-daudi-were|title=Ushahidi Board dismisses Executive Director, Daudi Were|website=Ushahidi|language=en-US|access-date=2017-08-16}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ushahidi.com/blog/2017/07/22/we-would-like-to-apologize-to-angela|title=We Would Like to Apologize to Angela|website=Ushahidi|language=en-US|access-date=2017-08-16}}</ref>
Ushahidi staff and staff from Ushahidi related organizations, under the banner "Women in Tech Kenya", released a statement on Jul 24 that supported Angela's speaking out, condemned Daudi Were's conduct, applauded his dismissal, and supporting the board following due process.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://medium.com/@womenintechke/the-road-ahead-in-building-the-kenyan-tech-ecosystem-perspectives-from-womenintechke-3c81df3943a4|title=The road ahead in building the Kenyan tech ecosystem: Perspectives from #WomenInTechKE|last=Kenya|first=Women in Tech|date=2017-07-24|website=Medium|access-date=2017-08-19}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://medium.com/@GeoForceKe/hello-ladies-48a418f6050|title=Hello Ladies.|last=Namnyek|first=Jane|date=2017-07-25|website=Jane Namnyek|access-date=2017-08-20}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://medium.com/@womenintechke/thank-you-for-reading-and-your-feedback-dcdfc44d47ac|title=Thank you for reading, and your feedback.|last=Kenya|first=Women in Tech|date=2017-07-25|website=Women in Tech Kenya|access-date=2017-08-20}}</ref>
The Ushahidi board did not resign and through a series of posts defended their conduct, saying that they followed due process in the pursuit of justice. In a statement released on July 28, Ushahidi said that due to the legal process, agreed upon by all parties, all communications had to go through the legal representation and called Ms. Kabari's claims that they did not care about her disingenuous for not understanding the neutral position the board undertook in the sexual harassment investigation.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ushahidi.com/blog/2017/07/28/information-for-ushahidi-funders-and-project-partners-regarding-the-recent-sexual-harassment-case|title=Information for Ushahidi funders and project partners regarding the recent sexual harassment case|website=Ushahidi|language=en-US|access-date=2017-08-16}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ushahidi.com/blog/2017/08/08/observations-regarding-sexual-harassment-cases|title=Observations Regarding Sexual Harassment Cases|website=Ushahidi|language=en-US|access-date=2017-08-16}}</ref>

'''Walumbe''' is a character in the Ganda [[creation myth]], [[The_legend_of_Kintu|The Legend of Kintu]]. He is the son of [[Ggulu]] and the brother of Nambi. His name is translated as "disease" or "death" and he is responsible for death on Earth according to Ganda mythology.
==The Legend==
In [[The_legend_of_Kintu|The Legend of Kintu]], after Kintu passes all of [[Ggulu]]'s tests, Ggulu gives him his daughter, Nambi, among other gifts to take back to Earth. He gives them multiple vegetable plants, a hen, and some millet. He warns them then to hurry back to Earth to avoid gaining the attention of Walumbe, Nambi's brother. He tells them not to come back for anything, but when Kintu forgets the hen's millet, he returns for it. After much deliberation, Kintu and Nambi allow Walumbe to stay with them on Earth for a time.
In tradition with Gandan culture, Walumbe, as a brother of the bride, claimed one of Kintu's children as his own. Kintu refuses Walumbe and continues to do so throughout the years. Frustrated, Walumbe, then begins to kill a single child every day. After conversing with [[Ggulu]], [[Kaikuzi]] is sent to aid Kintu in sending Walumbe back to heaven. Walumbe grapples with [[Kaikuzi]] and then retreats by digging and hiding within the ground. [[Kaikuzi]] soon tires of pursuing Warumbe and asks all of mankind to be silent for two days to lure Walumbe out. When Walumbe finally emerges, children cry out at the sight of him and he again retreats into the earth. Upon Kintu's dismissal, [[Kaikuzi]] then returns to [[Ggulu]] and explains the situation. Upon hearing of this, Ggulu allows Walumbe to remain on Earth.
Walumbe is therefore blamed as the reason for death on Earth.
==References== *Thury, Eva M. & Devinney, Margaret K. (2005). ''Introduction to Mythology'' . [[Oxford University Press]]. {{ISBN|978-0-19-517968-2}}

'''Woodblocks of the Nguyễn Dynasty''' ([[Vietnamese language|Vietnamese]]: ''Mộc bản triều Nguyễn'') is a collection of 34,555 plates of [[Woodcut|woodblock]] made during the reign of the [[Nguyễn Dynasty]] in which engraved various contents from official literature, history to classic and historical books. In 2009, this collection became the first entry of Vietnam in the list of [[UNESCO]]'s [[Memory of the World Programme]].
==Description== The total number of woodblock plates in the collection is 34,555 in which engraved various contents such as official literature, history as well as classic and historical books.<ref name=unesco/>
==Memory of the World== The collection of woodblocks of the Nguyễn Dynasty was the first submission by Vietnam to the Memory of the World Programme in 2008 and was officially registered in 2009, thus became the first Vietnamese entry.<ref name=unesco>{{cite web |url=http://portal.unesco.org/ci/en/ev.php-URL_ID=27338&URL_DO=DO_TOPIC&URL_SECTION=201.html |title=Woodblocks of Nguyen Dynasty |publisher=UNESCO}}</ref> According to UNESCO, the collection possesses not only historical value about [[List of Vietnamese monarchs|feudal dynasties]] in the [[history of Vietnam]] but also artistic and technical merit because from those plates, one can learn about the development of woodblock carving and printing profession in this country.<ref name=unesco/>
==See also== * [[Stone stele records of imperial examinations of the Lê and Mạc dynasties]], the second entry of Vietnam in the Programme
